body: Hello, please could you send me the `redis-server` executable that generated this issue? Thanks.

Update: tried to fuzz-testing clusterNodeRemoveSlave() and clusterNodeAddSlave() without success, they work as expected apparently for different set of operations, the memmove() looks fine and so forth. Must be something else. The binary and disassembling can definitely provide more hints.

Fuzzer I used for future references: https://gist.github.com/antirez/ca7f47d62516b0206cf6
I ran it with valgrind multiple times.

I'm running into what appears to be the same issue. On Debian Wheezy 3.2 x86_64 after a server crash redis is unable to start. I've also attached the redis-server executable.


[redis-server.gz](https://github.com/antirez/redis/files/89788/redis-server.gz)
hi, antirez, because I can't upload even zip or rar file to github, I send my binary "redis-server" file to your gmail box. Thanks for help.

hi, antirez. 
I run into the problem when I replaced a node in cluster. 
The attachment is the script and I run the command "./cluster.sh replace_node old_host old_port new_host new_port".

The main steps of  function  replace_node are :
    1 meet new node into cluster
    2 get master node id
    3 new node replicate master
    4 if old node is master then switch role between old node with new node 
    5 kick old node out of cluster
    6 shutdown old node

May this a little help for the problem!

[cluster.txt](https://github.com/antirez/redis/files/89965/cluster.txt)
Thanks! Very helpful info... I'll report ASAP with my findings.
@patrickswanson your bug appears unrelated, but I'll investigate it too in the context of this issue.
@JackyWoo please for the executable just send it to: antirez at gmail

So my first hypothesis that I'll verify in depth today is that `CLUSTER FORGET` may leave nodes with `node->slaveof` set to a node which is now deleted. Maybe this only happens only after node switches from master to slave or maybe it may happen always (need to check the code).
I sent binary redis-server to antirez@gmail.com .

@antirez Your  hypothesis is right.our scenario,A is master,have two slaves A1 and A2. Execute failover on A1 be promoed to new master.and execute forget A on the whole cluster nodes.On node B ,forget happend ahead,and then A2    exchange gossip message to B(one node),to tell B change new master to A1,the crash will happend.If change master happend ahead,will ok

Technically could be something like that (but with a master->slave switch where the original master is later listed as a slave, otherwise the function that releases the cluster node should be able to deal with it). However disassembling the binary it looks like it crashes at this line instead:

```
        if (master->slaves[j] == slave) {
```

When trying to deference master->slaves[0]. No idea how that could ever happen so far since there is no obvious code path where master->slaves is not take in sync with master->numslaves.

So this is what I think happens in details, that can justify this outcome, removing all the intermediate steps that happen in actual situations, so in the middle between 1, 2, 3 many other things could happen:
1. Master A turns into slave.
2. Some other node X is notified of the switch.
3. When X updates the node A to turn it into a slave, it just calls `clusterNodeResetSlaves()`. The function does not care about setting all the slaves `slaveof` field to NULL.
4. Later X is reached by `CLUSTER FORGET A`, so A no longer exists in X memory, but still it got other nodes pointing to its address in `slaveof`.
5. X receives change of master info for some slave which used to have A as master. When this happens, we access a `slaveof` pointer which is invalid.

There are two fixes, one is conservative, one is more "correct" but more fragile.
1. Conservative fix: when freeClusterNode() is called, instead of just freeing what appears to be in the `node->slaves` list, we scan all the nodes, and set any `node->slaveof` field set to the node we are freeing, to NULL.
2. Correct minimal fix: just make sure that clusterNodeResetSlaves() sets slaves to NULL.

I like more `2` because if there are more bugs we'll find it, but does a work proportional to the slaves for this past master, and not proportional to the number of nodes. Fixing it in a second and closing the issue. **Thanks for your help!** Please report more bugs.

Again:

## Thanks! Collaborating in bug reports is the best you can do for Redis.
Fix is a bit more complicated than expected in order to pick the right solution... Fix will be available likely tomorrow. Thanks.

Ok finally pushed a fix, should be the final one... I want to see a couple of runs of redis-cluster test in the CI btw, but it's the safest change I could think of. Details are in the commit message log. The fix will be backported to all the other branches of course, currently is just `unstable`.
ok, thanks very much for your work, we will pull the code and test it.

Thanks, I'm still testing stuff and doing code auditing around this patch and the general mechanism to take n->slaveof and n->slaves synchronized, it's not totally impossible that I'll change the code a bit more, but testing of this patch as provided is very appreciated, thank you.
